node.text:
America is reeling from a failed war in Afghanistan, political polarisation and increasing social division. Could the superpower be in decline?

Cover image credit: AFP

node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
Will America’s vaccine mandates work? On “The Economist Asks” podcast host Anne McElvoy speaks to Dr Scott Gottlieb, the former commissioner of America’s Food and Drug Administration.⁠
⁠
On the podcast, Mr Gottlieb describes how political polarisation complicated the pandemic response in America. The author of “Uncontrolled Spread” also assesses how future epidemics can be squashed earlier and the efficacy of booster shots.⁠
⁠
To also hear how he cooks his steak for safety and taste, click the link in our bio to listen to “The Economist Asks”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Greece. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person, playing a musical instrument, guitar and indoor.

node.text:
The opening of the theme tune to “Zorba the Greek” is quite possibly the most famous two­-note phrase in post-war European music.⁠
⁠
Yet five years after “Zorba”, Mikis Theodorakis, the composer, is living in internal exile in his homeland, Greece. His music has been banned, it was said, for arousing passions and causing strife among the people. ⁠
⁠The Greek colonels who had seized power in 1967 judged his compositions to be in the service of communism. He wrote a poem called “I had three lives”. ⁠
⁠
He used the theme of three lives in his work to braid together all the threads that gave his life meaning: boundless artistic energy, heroic political struggle and private love and sorrow.⁠
⁠
Mikis Theodorakis died on September 2nd, aged 96. To read about the day when his three lives came together, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Photopress Archiv/Keystone⁠

node.text:
Welcome to the decentralised “metaverse”. In this looking-glass land, cartoonish avators roam digital shops and spend money via your crypto-wallet.⁠
⁠
Sounds bewildering? Rightly so. Huge changes are happening in the world of finance and crypto-currencies are at the core.⁠
⁠
If you thought the crypto-revolution was more for “believers” than for you, then think again.⁠
⁠
Ethereum, a blockchain network, verified transactions worth $2.5trn in the second quarter, around the same sum as Visa processes.⁠
⁠
And the dream of a low-friction financial system, built on the likes of Ethereum, may be just the beginning.⁠
⁠
In our cover this week we explain how money is being reshaped by tech platforms, big government and decentralised finance. Click on the link in our bio to read about “DeFi”.⁠
⁠
Credit: Credit: Justin Metz/Alamy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people.

node.text:
Muhammad Ali was as brave as he was brilliant; happily, few athletes today are called upon to risk so much.⁠
⁠
Long before his conversion to Islam and stance on Vietnam, Ali was booed by crowds and loathed by the wider public—for his cockiness, his opinions and the fact that he had them. ⁠
⁠
Both Muhammad Ali and Martin Luther King came to be revered for their principles and courage, but were first, and for years, reviled for them. Like the fighters who only bested him after he should have quit, the world had been slow to catch up.⁠
⁠
Few stories can sustain eight hours of television, but Muhammad Ali’s is one of them. Back Story, our new culture column, assesses a new four-part documentary series about the boxer, click to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Courtesy of John Rooney / AP Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of text that says 'Briefing Innovation in decentralised finance could improve the real-world industry'.

node.text:
A growing number of developers are seeking to rebuild both the financial system and the internet economy using blockchains—databases distributed over many computers and kept secure by cryptography.⁠
⁠
Far from the self-aggrandising ambition of Wall Street, decentralised finance (DeFi) instead seeks Utopian-sounding crowdsourced control.⁠
⁠
The ultimate goal is to replace the likes of global banks and tech platforms with software built on top of networks that direct the value they generate back to the users who own and run them.⁠
⁠
Talk of blockchains, “decentralised autonomous organisations” (DAOs) and metaverses can sound utterly bewildering and the success of DeFi is far from guaranteed. ⁠
⁠
But the nascent technology could amount to something meaningful and powerfully disruptive.⁠
⁠
Our correspondent immersed herself in the DeFi vision to understand why people are bothering to decentralise the world of finance. ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why the potential gains from it could be vast.⁠
⁠
Credit: @mikeljaso

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of ‎1 person and ‎text that says '‎Britain ۔'w to be a post-populist prime minister‎'‎‎.

node.text:
One task of a post-populist is to pick up the pieces, which requires a “quiet, unflashy decency and competence”, says a friend of Sir Keir Starmer. ⁠
⁠
The Labour leader sees Britain’s biggest problems as insecure work and the hollowing-out of public services. Can he be the one to solve them?⁠
⁠
Both Labour’s and Sir Keir’s ratings are poor. Covid-19 has robbed him of opportunities to campaign and influence the news agenda. But his supporters are hoping that after the tumult of Brexit and Jeremy Corbyn’s hard-left populism, voters are hankering for stability and professionalism. ⁠
⁠
His electoral chances now depend on two questions. To find out what they are, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Mumbai, Maharashtra. May be an image of 1 person, train and railroad.

node.text:
South Asia has a long history of gender diversity. Estimates of the number of non-binary people in Bangladesh, India and Pakistan run from 500,000 to several million.⁠
⁠
The region has a plethora of terms for people who identify neither as male nor female. The best known is "hijra". ⁠
⁠
Hijras feature in the mythology surrounding Ram, an important Hindu deity. They have long been associated with spiritual powers.⁠
⁠
But now the term “transgender” has arrived in South Asia after gaining global currency. And some hijras are worried about losing their identity.⁠
⁠
Transgender protection acts require India's "third gender" to register as trans, a process that can require medical proof of gender reassignment, which most hijras do not undergo.⁠
⁠
Many of the people who ought to benefit from new protection laws are riled by what they see as lawmakers’ perpetuation of long-held misconceptions. Click the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Sara Hylton / Redux / eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Utah. May be an image of sky, lake and text that says 'United States Salt Lake City is one of the biggest winners of the past decade 命'.

node.text:
There are few places in America that can crow louder about their successes in the past decade than Salt Lake City.⁠
⁠
The City of the Saints has the lowest jobless rate among all big cities, at 2.8%, compared with a national rate of 5.2%.⁠
⁠
Utah has rebounded well from the downturn caused by the covid-19 pandemic, thanks to the Wasatch Front. The four counties that make up the urban corridor account for at least 80% of Utah’s economic activity, reckons one economist.⁠
⁠
Having the most most diverse economy of any state helps too.⁠
⁠
In many ways Salt Lake’s success mirrors what is happening in other cities in the Mountain West, such as Boise, Idaho, and Denver, Colorado. ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read what makes Utah so exceptional.⁠
⁠
Credit: Lindsay D'Addato/The New York Times/ eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 18, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Finance Gary Gensler has big ambitions for the SEC. Does he have the big bucks?'.

node.text:
“Operation Tame Finance” has begun at the SEC under Gary Gensler.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
From crypto to trading apps, Mr Gensler has to work out how, and to what extent, to police the explosion of innovation that has upended finance.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
He used to teach diligent undergraduates. By contrast, regulating financial markets is like running the world’s largest, noisiest kindergarten.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Still, Mr Gensler has big ambitions for America’s main markets watchdog. But, as our Buttonwood columnist argues, he may not have the big bucks. To read about the challenges that await the SEC’s new chairman, tap on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @satillustration

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'GERMANY IS NOT AS STABLE AS WE THINK. JUST ASK ITS PREPPERS'.

node.text:
Apocalypse prepping used to be the domain of oddballs and billionaires. But now small business owners in Germany are plunging in. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
For many Germans it’s not hard to imagine what preppers call TEOTWAWKI (The End of The World As We Know It). When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, institutions that had governed every aspect of people’s lives vanished overnight. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Now they want to be ready. Due to the financial crisis of 2007-2009, the increased tempo of extreme-weather events and the coronavirus pandemic, more people have been drawn to the apocalypse preparation movement. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In Germany preppers generally fall into two categories: neo-Nazis, and everyone else. Some on the far right seem to be attracted to prepping because it chimes with their sense that the modern democratic state is weak, as well as the opportunities it offers to spend time with weapons. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Yet most of the people buying bunkers in Berlin are average citizens, click the link in bio to read more. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Credit: Ewelina Karpowiak

node.text:
⁠“L’Événement”, a poignant abortion drama, won the top prize at Venice Film Festival last weekend.⁠
⁠
The French drama, co-written and directed by Audrey Diwan, was adapted from Annie Ernaux’s memoir.⁠
⁠
“L’Événement” (“The Happening”) tells the story of a young woman who wants to terminate her pregnancy.⁠
⁠
It may be set in 1963, but the subject feels grimly contemporary, considering the legislation recently passed in Texas which prohibits abortion after six weeks.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read our review of the film and why its success adds to what is already a momentous year in the history of film awards.⁠
⁠
Credit: Capital Pictures⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power " In this multipolar age, the world's best hope remains an essential measure of American leadership Gordon Brown'.

node.text:
Just when we need more multilateralism, we have less, says Gordon Brown.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The crisis of covid-19 vaccine distribution illustrates the problem. New variants will “haunt us all” unless the West commits to vaccinating poorer countries as widely as rich ones, writes Britain’s former prime minister in a commentary for The Economist.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Yet if the world can’t distribute covid vaccines equitably, how can it respond to other global challenges—and what role does America play?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The country “can no longer define itself as the sole sphere of influence in this new multipolar world, nor should it have to face the world on its own,” Mr Brown argues.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Still, America has “not yet found a role”, he notes. To do so, it must “imagine a world in which it is no longer the only superpower”. To read why he believes becoming the “world’s problem-solver” is the best next step for the future of American power, click on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will
